Colin, what are the 12 sensors or so that I see in the genome file? 
It looks there are 8 sensors around the body of the predator.

One thing that would really help the predator is to make its world
egocentric.  In other words, make it like a robot on wheels with a
heading.  The sensors would be relative to the heading, instead of
always pointing in the same direction, i.e. the robot could turn
around.  I find that kind of sensor array is much more natural than a
staticly positioned sensor array, which forces the NN to have to learn
basically the same rule over and over again for each sensor.  With
egocentric sensors, the robot can just say "if the target is in the
forward sensor, go to it."  The other sensors then just tell it how to
turn.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Ok there is another release on the SharpNEAT web site 
> http://www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/
> 
> This includes a deterministic prey capture evaluator as described
in my 
> previous email. I normally see this solved within 100,000
evaluations 
> (see new eval counter in the GUI) using the default search
parameters. 
> Once this task is solved the evaluator switches to the old 
> non-deterministic approach (random start positions, varying prey
initial 
> moves and speed) - unfortunately this part didn't work at all well,
I 
> didn't see any improvement, in fact the networks lost some of their
old 
> ability, presumably because the random trials don't test every bit
of 
> functionality and therfore some can be lost from one generation to
the 
> next.
> 
> It did just occur to me though that the non-deterministic trials
can be 
> made deterministic very easily by resetting the random number
generator 
> before each set of trials. I just tried this and it does seem to
work - 
> the best fitness stabilizes whereas before it could be seen to vary
- 
> but the best fitness now seems stuck at 61 and 63 out of 64 in the
two 
> trials I am running
> 
> Anyway there is a saved network in the zip that performs perfectly
on 
> the pre-determined tests. In the prey capture evaluator click on
the 
> "Initialise [Deterministic]"  button - this loops through the 16
start 
> positions. If you then set the prey initial moves to 3 and the
speed to 
> 0 and click on the 'Step' button to see the deterministic trial. 
You 
> can of course still run the preycapture simulation automatically
but 
> this uses random start positions (distance 0-4) and therefore you
may 
> not see perfect results.
> 
> Colin.
> 
> Colin Green wrote:
> 
> >Kenneth Stanley wrote:
> >
> >  
> >
> >>>Hey Colin, just out of curiosity what was the fine tuning that
> >>>improved things?  
> >>>
> >>>
> >>>   
> >>>
> >>>      
> >>>
> >Hi Ken,
> >
> >I'll probably write up what I did in detail on the web site, just 
> >quickly though I had a think about what you said about
randomization in 
> >the trials, so whereas before I used 100 randomized trials and
gradually 
> >increased the difficulty by giving the prey 0 to 4 initial moves an
then 
> >increasing it's speed, I am now running 32 predefined trials. 16
tests 
> >with the prey starting within sensor range and not moving and
another 16 
> >using the same start positions but allowing the prey 3 initial
moves. 
> >The initial moves are also deterministic in that the prey moves
directly 
> >away from the agent and this also has the effect of moving the prey
out 
> >of sensor range - by then though the agent has received inputs with
the 
> >prey's location, so it has chance to remember where they prey was
seen. 
> >These tests are passed 100% but do not produce a perfect agent -
it 
> >still can't chase moving prey with a 4 move head start in all test 
> >cases, although it does perform pretty well actually :). Anyway
this 
> >situation should be resolvable by extending the trials to contain 
> >further more difficult tests or by switching completely to a more 
> >difficult trial  i.e.incremental evolution.  In fact I may be able
to 
> >revert to my original randomized trials once a good population has
been 
> >found.
> >
> >Colin.
> >
